choices.A: It instructs the hub to disable the reordering of TCP packets on behalf of the receiver, to improve performance.
choices.C: It instructs the hub to not check the ESP sequence numbers on IPsec traffic, to improve performance.
choices.D: It instructs the hub to skip content inspection on TCP traffic, to improve performance.
choices.B: It instructs the hub to disable TCP sequence number check, which is required for TCP sessions originated from spokes to fail over back and forth between the hubs.

Page : 359 on 7.2 Guide

choices.B: FortiGate performs routing lookups for new sessions only, after a route change.
choices.C: FortiGate always blocks all traffic, after a route change.
choices.A: FortiGate does not change the routing information on existing sessions that use a valid gateway, after a route change.
choices.D: FortiGate flushes all routing information from the session table, after a route change.

choices.C: You do not need to enable SSL inspection.
choices.A: The traffic always skips the regular policy routes.
choices.D: You do not need to configure firewall policies that accept the SD-WAN traffic.
choices.B: You steer traffic based on the detected application.
